conclusion: Understand the system with three logs forming an isosceles triangle.
Log A is in equilibrium, so forces must balance.
Resolve vertical forces on Log A: 2F cos 60° = F = mg.
Horizontal component of normal force on Log A is F sin 60° = mg √3/2.
Logs B and C must balance horizontal force from Log A with static friction.
Horizontal component from Log A equals frictional force: f = mg √3/2.
Relate frictional force to normal force: f = μN, where N = mg.
Solve for μ: mg √3/2 = μmg, so μ = √3/2.
The dynamic friction factor μ is √3/2.
